data.text: Is the 650b Slower Than 700c?
659b vs 700c. Is 650b really that much slower? I'm not competing for podiums in events but I would like to at least be competitive(podium someday)
It is a great way to get a wider tire.
data.author: Jock DeBoer

data.text: yes, that's my plan, but will I regret it is the question
data.author: Andrew Huff

data.text: I have 2 pair. Love them for the winter or mud. They make the steering a bit quicker
data.author: Jock DeBoer

data.text: I have 2 bikes, a Specialized Sequoia with 42 x 700c and a Salsa Journeyman with 55 x 650b. I like both but the Specialized hasn't seen a ride in over a year. I love the cushion the 650b gives me. And I keep up just fine
data.author: Jason Lofton

data.text: It's not really slower, there are definitely some advantages to be had with 650b for gravel bikes
data.author: David Miller

data.text: If you're trying to be truly competitive, yes there's a marginal difference. If you're just trying to have a good time it's infinitesimally small.
data.author: Ted Redmer

data.text: If you're more on trails go with the 650b.
data.author: Leonard Ian Mendiola

data.text: if you want a gravel friendly (not full blown mtb) you will find wider tires common for 650. 700 has lots of up to 42 wide tires but higher get rarer. some of my favorite tire styles are 650. but im not sure theres many slick style 650s
data.author: Jordan Nickel

data.text: I've found very few 650 slicks. 29er mountain tires fit 700 rims but there does seem to be a gap between 42mm (guessing 1.5 inches) and then you're all the way to 2.1 and higher. I used to love the 1.95 width for gravel riding back in the 90's.
data.author: Thomas M Leaidicker

data.text: that's pretty much exatwhat I've experienced. I'd be surprised if panaracer doesn't make atleast a semi slick in 650. But I've never looked. The closest in between for 700 I found was a 68. But I was trying to aim for a 50. Ended up just getting a set of minor knobbles in 2.1. hated them. They were seriously heavy. So I went back to my Conti speedrides
data.author: Jordan Nickel

data.text: never tried the speedride. I have the Conti Cross King in 32mm which I've been quite impressed with their corner grip when I get on trails.
data.author: Thomas M Leaidicker

data.text: I've been a Big fan of my speedrides. And I would have kept them on my main bike. But It was pushing it a bit on width. And I found a set of smaller giant tires (random pull offs)
data.author: Jordan Nickel

data.text: Ted King doesn’t think so. He races on 650. He’s quite fast.
data.author: Jesse Rushton

data.text: not for everything I don't think. Pretty sure he's been running 700c for most of his races like Unbound.
data.author: Benjamin Arians

data.text: totally agree! I’m not pro by any stretch but my 650b x 48 mm cannondale lefty is just as fast as my 700c pivot vault with zipp 303 wheels.

data.text: he hasn't run 650b since 2016

data.text: no he doesn’t. He runs 700c Rene Herse tires.

data.text: , Yes, you are correct. Like what you said, he uses 650b wheels for specific races (in 2020, he did the Cross-Vermont on a set of Zipp Firecrest 650b wheels) and 700c for other races like the Gravel Unbound.

data.text: some courses the 650b makes sense, when there is a lot of up and down, and rough terrain, the smaller wheel size combined with fatter tire makes a lot of sense.
data.author: Benjamin Arians

data.text: 700c for mostly road, 650b for mostly trails. Happy on either for gravel. At least for me. A lot of it depends on gearing though.
data.author: Skeevi Strauss

data.text: You need 29s. Or 700c
data.author: Mallory McGuire

data.text: N+1 doesn’t just apply to bikes, it applies to wheel sets too 🙂. I enjoy the playful feel of 650’s. Go wide on the tire for more cush and to keep your pedal strike less impactful. I run 650x2.2 Conti RaceKings and they roll very well.
data.author: Steve Curran

data.text: 29x2.0 with a light casing was my favorite gravel tire. Conti race kings. Now I just ride my MTB on gravel. 29x2.4 and 1 gear hahaha
data.author: Matt Evans

data.text: I love 650b and have had some of my fastest gravel races on 650bx47 WTB Byway.
data.author: John Shoemaker

data.text: I’ve ripped single track on my 700x38 tires
data.author: Reed Osell

data.text: Rider weight is going to play a role as well. For more rubenesque riders 700C might not provide enough cushion before you start burping tires or popping tubes where as 650bs have much more air volume for actual trails with roots and rocks.
data.author: Mikey Mutz

data.text: for a given width a bigger diameter will have more air volume.
data.author: Andrew Yee

data.text: 650b x 47 has about 25% more volume than a 700CX40. There is a huge difference in ability for a fluffier rider to drop pressure.
data.author: Mikey Mutz

data.text: "for a given width"
data.author: Andrew Yee

data.text: but no one is running a 650B at the same width they are running a 700C. Otherwise you would just run a 700C. You're arguing to argue.
data.author: Mikey Mutz

data.text: I've toured with 26, 27.5, 29. IMO 27.5 provides the most comfortable ride overall. I've been using 27.5 tubeless setup for 4 years now without any issues. Current setup Zipp 303s with Maxxis Rambler 47mm.
data.author: Dave Becker-Ellison

data.text: I’d totally be rocking 650’s if they worked on Those Horrible Chamois Hagars. I had a set with a Dynamo hub that I intended to swap between 2 bikes. I liked them on my OPEN, even though I could only fit a 1.9 on the back.
data.author: Justin M Short BA

data.text: To me the main advantages of 650 is that it's more nimble, so if you're on trails or have really tight corners there's a handling advantage. Second advantage is it fits in the back of the van easier. 700 or 29 inch wheels simply maintain rolling speed with less effort and in a trail application, roll over obstacles easier. I say keep a wheelset of both, ride both and use whichever is best suited to you and your terrain.
data.author: Thomas M Leaidicker

data.text: Wheel sizes, 700c vs 650b, has been a hot debate over the past several years and comes up for discussion often. I have seen so many comparisons of 650b to 700c wheels, but they always (literally) are also comparing different width volume tires so to me that’s comparing apples to oranges. To get a true comparison of wheel sizes you have to compare them with the same size tire at the same “relative” pressure. Personally I think the primary reason to change from 700c (29”) to 650b (27.5”) is if you “need” to. Through my personal, extensive, back to back testing with both size wheels with the same model/width tires, at “similar pressures” wider tires run lower pressures), I believe the the 700c wheels to be superior in nearly all instances provided you are comparing with similar width/volume tires. The larger diameter circumference rolls noticeable smoother over rough terrain than the 650s. They also tend to carry your speed into, through, and out of a corner better when compared to the 650s. The 650s do feel quicker on tight twisty singletrack, but I don’t feel that makes up for the smoothness and speed of the 700s with the same size/pressure tires. The most obvious sensation when switching between the 2 (with the same size tires) is that the 700s roll noticeably smoother and faster than the 650s and when switching to the 650s the first thing you notice is the bike feels lower (but that quickly goes away) and then it’s quicker on tight twisty trails. The thing is you don’t feel the lack of quickness with the 700s, and you don’t feel the lack of smoothness with the 650s unless you compair them back to back on the same piece of trail. Personally I’ll take smooth fast and efficient over quickness in most cases, and I spend over 70% of my time on singletrack. That said there are times when switching to a 650b wheelset would be beneficial. I think the main reason to make the switch would be if your frame is limited to about a 700c x 40mm tire but can accommodate at least a 10mm wider tire in the 650b size. So in this example let’s say 700 x 40mm or 650 x 52mm. If this were your scenario and you rode primarily smooth gravel and pavement I think the 700 x 40mm would be the logical choice. Now if you primarily rode rough, loose, dirt, or technical singletrack where the added traction, quickness, and comfort of the wider 52mm tire would be appreciated, then the 650bs might be preferred. In this case (700 x 40mm or 650 x 52mm) you could go with either wheel size, or even both. If your frame can already fit up to a 700 x 48mm or larger tire I would typically prefer that route. While personally I was all set on 29 x 2.0” (700 x 50.8mm) I recently converted the forks on my MCR to 80mm for the rowdier trails so I’ve gone with 27.5 x 2.3” front and 2.2” in rear. It’s nice to not tiptoe through the rocks as much as my wicked fast, but delicate Furious Freds. The other circumstance in which I think the 650b wheelset would be beneficial is if your a “compact” rider on a small frame it’s the logical choice. It’s really tough to minimize toe overlap with a large volume 700c tire. Also the lower standover height and center of gravity is beneficial especially to the smaller riders. So here’s “Jake’s Rule” - If you can fit at least a 10mm wider tire in a 650b than a 700c tire in your frame, you are a shorter rider, or ride more technical terrain, then 650b wheels are an option to consider 🐍 * A special shout out to my “main man” of speedvisionbikes.com If you ever need a set of wheels contact him and tell him Jake the Snake sent you and he’ll take good care of you!

data.text: I could fit 700x40 or 650b x47. I'm interested in the 650 mainly for flowy rooty single track. The gravel in my area is usually pretty compacted and smooth so I don't want to sacrifice to much speed. Although I guess i could just keep two wheelsets

data.text: Thank you for this detailed post. Really appreciate the analysis.
data.author: Drew Harris

data.text: Same bike but set up with the 650bs. A big advantage for riding MTB trails with the 27.5s is that I can fit a 27.5” x 2.35 in front, and a 2.2” in back. With 700c I’m Limited to a 2.1” in back, and just barely at that. A lot of rubber can be a good thing in the rocks and roots 😉
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: For comfort and trails I like 650b if you are mostly going in a straight line go with 700c
data.author: Jonathan Smith

data.text: that’s true to a point. Because if you can fit the same width tire on a 650b or 700c wheel the 700s will be noticeably smoother and comfortable.
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: it's actually the opposite. on the 650b you will have a higher sidewall and that is more comfortable. Same as with car wheels/tires. 17" rims are more comfortable than 20"s
data.author: Chris Andrews

data.text: say what? I think you misread my reply. A 27.5” x 2.1” tire has the same width and height as a 29” x 2.1” tire when fitted in the same width rim. The difference is the overall diameter. I know because I had both identical model tires mounted on wheels and did back to back 4km loops of singletrack and fire roads for comparison. The reason widths are rated differently (700 x 42 or 650 x 50) on frames is because at the larger diameter most frames tend to get narrower the closer you get to the bottom bracket 😉🐍✌🏼
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: yes the tire with a higher sidewall will have more compliance so softer ride, 700c x 38 is same overall diameter in height as 650b x 50 ( I am guessing on size) but I think the overall wheel may have more weight and a little less aerodynamic, but those are marginal differences performance wise
data.author: Jonathan Smith

data.text: sure your talking “same diameter” now, my statement was in regards to “same width”. That’s also why I said “true to a point” because most people can’t fit a large diameter 700c tire in their frames 😉
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: yes I think he did miss understand or something wasn't worded well , one day I'll have to try 650b but I don't personally need 50mm tires as I have a mountain bike for that lol, goes pretty fast with xc tires too

data.text: I have both and the 650s have been the big surprise. I thought they’d be a “once in a while” set and turns out they see way more miles than my 700s. They are almost as fast on tarmac and much faster on single track, gravel is even imo. Above all, they are just more fun. Steering is quicker and they spin up faster making it easier to get back up to speed on technical stuff. I run Boyd CCC wheels with Maxxis Rekon Race 2.25s for what it’s worth. On the 700s I’m on Roval C38s with IRC Boken Doublecross 42s.
data.author: Scott Greencard Evans

data.text: I run three wheelsets on the gravel bike: a WTB 700c wheelset with Conti Gator HardShell 32mm; a GRX 700c wheelset with Conti TerraTrail 40mm; and a GRX 650b that used to have WTB Sendero 47mm. Looking for a Conti replacement, but my 650b's were raced more times than my 700c's have been.
data.author: T.j. Oehmen

data.text: I've had 29 ,700c & I find 650 with a wider tyre much more comfortable with a 2.8" tyre , but then again I've got a bike with 26"x 2.1" four touring .

data.author: Tom Edwards

data.text: There are a couple of ways to look at it.... If you compare a 700x45c and a 650bx45c in the same tire on the same wheels. 650b will accelerate slightly faster and be more agile. The 700c will maintain it's momentum and provide a smoother faster ride. If you're going to compare 700x45 or 27.5x2.2 because that's the options of what fits in the chainstays....the 27.5x2.2 will be about the same size as the 700x45 but with more volume and have similar riding characteristics and around the same weight...what you end up with is more tire volume in the 650b which will handle off road better.
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: great description!

data.text: 45=1.77”

data.text: It's subjective. My first ride on 650b felt slower, but I hit 9 prs on Strava. 🤷🏼‍♂️. But I also don't really care about speed.

data.text: I dig my 650 setup with a little lower pressure. I like a supple ride.
data.author: Ryan Phillis

data.text: I dont think it matters half as much as people may think. Ride what you feel most confident on, mentality makes more difference than any marginal percent advantage (at an amateur level)
data.author: Friedrich Cody

data.text: What 650? Vs what 700? Like grav? Mtb? Road? Descending in the hills and chunky stuff 29” or 700c is faster being that you can roll over chunky stuff easier where as 650 would be more nimble. So kinda depends really.
data.author: Levi Turner

data.text: grav grav. And single track on the gravel bike. The gravel near me is super smooth hardpack(mostly) the single track is loose and root filled.
data.author: Andrew Huff

data.text: I had the same dilemma. Ended up purchasing a Kona Rove LTD with 650b x 47 tires. I love it, even though most of my riding is on hardpack and even pavement. I have tires great for hardpack and pavement, Maxxis Minion Recpetor 650b x 47. I am plenty fast enough, even on pavement. However, I bought my Rove with two front rings 48 and 31, so it would function as a gravel bike and as a touring bike, with bags if I wanted too. I have four bikes, but the Rove gets ridden the most. The ride on the 650b x 47 tires is so smooth and dampens vibration and bumps. Tire circumference matter but so does gearing. Calculate the gear inches that you desire for your possible tire decision and sprocket combinations to determine the differences. I spoke to another rider who bought two set of wheels for their Rove, both 700c and 650b but rides the 650b almost exclusively. I am lead to believe that 700c may roll a little faster in a given gear but 650b helps in quicker acceleration.
data.author: Todd McKinnon
